title: Repository
definition: A repository is a storage space for your project’s files and version history.
example: A repo for your website code lets you track changes over time.
tip: Keep your README.md updated for clarity.

title: Branch
definition: A branch is a separate line of development.
example: Create a 'feature-login' branch to work safely without touching main.
tip: Avoid committing directly to main in team projects.

title: Commit
definition: A commit saves a snapshot of your changes.
example: Commit after fixing a bug to record the update.

title: Merge
definition: Merging combines changes from one branch into another.

title: Clone
definition: Cloning copies a remote repository to your local machine.
example: Clone a teammate’s repo to start contributing.
tip: Use git clone with the correct URL.

title: Pull Request
definition: A pull request proposes changes for review before merging.
example: Open a PR to add a new feature.

title: Remote
definition: A remote is a version of your repository hosted elsewhere, like GitHub.
example: Push changes to the 'origin' remote on GitHub.
tip: Check remote URLs with git remote -v.

title: Staging Area
definition: The staging area holds changes before committing.
example: Add files to staging with git add.
tip: Review staged files with git status.
diagram: Box between working directory and commit

title: Fork
definition: A fork is a personal copy of someone else’s repository.
example: Fork a library to customize it for your needs.
tip: Sync your fork with the original repo regularly.
diagram: Branch splitting off from main tree

title: Conflict
definition: A conflict happens when changes in different branches overlap.
example: Both branches edit the same line in README.md.

title: Tag
definition: A tag marks a specific point in history, often for releases.
example: Tag v1.0.0 for your first stable release.

title: Checkout
definition: Checkout switches branches or restores files.
example: Checkout 'develop' to work on new features.
